item.title: China and US Holding Second Day of Trade Talks in London
item.description: Talks between the US and China extended later into their second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

item.title: Key Republican Senator Expects ‘Revenge’ Tax to Be Delayed
item.description: Republican Senator Thom Tillis said he expects the implementation of the Section 899 “revenge tax” in President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending bill to be delayed as it faces pushback from Wall Street and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

item.title: India, US to Expedite Trade Talks Ahead of Trump’s Tariff Deadline
item.description: India and the US will expedite trade talks to conclude an agreement that includes “early wins” for both sides, an official said, as the two nations race to clinch a deal before Washington’s tit-for-tat tariffs kick in next month.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Navi Mumbai, India.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s ZiG Currency: How Does It Work, and Can It Last?
item.description: Zimbabwe’s gold-backed currency, the ZiG, is already suffering from the same lack of credibility that doomed its predecessors.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: John Mushayavanhu holds up a specimen of the new gold backed currency ZiG banknote , in Harare. Photographer: Cynthia R Matonhodze/Bloomberg

item.title: Kenya Cuts Key Rate for Sixth Time in Row to Prop Up Economy
item.description: Kenya’s central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for the sixth time in a row to help shore up the economy as inflation is expected to remain benign.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians in the financial district in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Brits Hoarding Cash Amid Global Volatility, Says Bank of England Official
item.description: The rising number of British banknotes in circulation suggests households are hoarding cash as they face times of extreme uncertainty and the possibility of network outages, according to a Bank of England official.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Argentina Bonds Rise on New Measures to Lure Dollars
item.description: Argentina’s bonds gained Tuesday after the central bank unveiled a slew of measures aimed at helping the South American nation amass more hard-currency reserves, firepower the country needs to meet dollar debt payments.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

item.title: ECB Can Wait Until September to Even Discuss Next Rate Move, Vujcic Says
item.description: The European Central Bank should wait until at least September to have an in-depth discussion about an interest-rate move, according to Governing Council member Boris Vujcic.
item.dc:creator: Kriti Gupta, Jasmina Kuzmanovic, Mark Schroers

item.title: US Small-Business Sentiment Increases for First Time This Year
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses rose in May for the first time in 2025 as firms grew more upbeat about the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A hardware store in San Francisco.

item.title: World Bank Warns 2020s Face Weakest Global Growth Since 1960s
item.description: The World Bank on Tuesday cut its forecast for global growth this year and warned that the 2020s are on track for the weakest performance for any decade since the first Apollo moon landing because of trade tensions and policy uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: Zambia Sees Economic Growth Surging to Highest Since 2021
item.description: Zambia’s economy will expand at least 6% this year as Africa’s second-largest copper producer reaps the benefit of improved rainfall and higher metal production, the finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Copper plates on wagons ready for shipping at a refinery in Mufulira, Zambia.

item.title: Brazil Inflation Slows Amid Market Rift on June Rate Meeting
item.description: Brazil’s annual inflation eased more than expected in May, snapping three months of advances before central bankers meet to decide whether or not to extend their aggressive cycle of interest rate hikes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati

item.title: More Canadians Are Ditching US Road Trips With 38% Annual Drop
item.description: Cross-border road trips to the US from Canada fell for a fifth straight month, a gloomy outlook for many American vacation spots once frequented by their northern neighbors during the peak summer travel season.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A vehicle traveling into the United States at the Canada-US border in St-Bernard-de-Lacolle, Quebec, Canada, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. President Donald Trump exempted Canadian goods covered by the North American trade agreement known as USMCA from his 25% tariffs, offering major reprieves to the US’s two largest trading partners.

item.title: Traders Price in Two More BOE Rate Cuts After Weak Jobs Data
item.description: Traders ramped up bets on interest-rate cuts from the Bank of England to fully price two more quarter-point reductions this year, after data showed a sharp deterioration in the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Trump Tariffs Threaten to Derail US Midwest’s Factory Revival
item.description: The Midwestern US, which accounts for almost a third of all manufacturing jobs and production output in America, was devastated when factory employment went offshore two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: How the ‘Long Bond’ Showcases America’s Budget Deterioration
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today, we’re looking at increasing worries about the US budget outlook, as seen through the 30-year bond. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Spain to See Slowest Quarterly Growth in Two Years, Central Bank Forecasts
item.description: Spain’s economy will grow at the slowest pace in almost two years this quarter, according to new forecasts from the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

item.title: IMF Wants Zimbabwe’s Gold-Backed ZiG to Become Sole Currency
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said it would like to see the ZiG “fully becoming a national currency,” as it weighs whether to place Zimbabwe on a staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

item.title: Afreximbank Says Fitch Rating Cut Based on ‘Erroneous View’
item.description: African Export-Import Bank lashed out at Fitch Ratings saying its decision to cut its assessment to one step above junk with a negative outlook was based on a false premise.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: The African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) Annual Meeting in Accra, Ghana. Photographer: Ernest Ankomah/Getty Images Europe

item.title: France’s Finance Minister Is the Calm Hand Macron Needs Now
item.description: Eric Lombard is deploying his deal making skills to avert political turmoil
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard, France's finance minister, at the AI Action Summit in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. France is set to announce a total of €109 billion in investment in artificial intelligence projects in the country by companies, funds and other sources over the coming years, President Emmanuel Macron said on the eve of a two-day AI Action Summit.

item.title: Germany Grants Record Citizenships With Big Increase in Russians
item.description: The number of people granted German citizenship jumped by almost 50% to another record last year, with Syrians again fueling the surge as well as a significant increase in the naturalization of Russians.
item.dc:creator: Iain Rogers

item.title: German New Home Prices Rise to Record on Construction Slump
item.description: Prices for new homes in Germany rose to a record in May as housing shortages drive demand, underscoring the urgency facing Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s government to make good on a pledge to boost residential construction.
item.dc:creator: Laura Malsch

media:content.media:description: Apartment buildings under construction in Berlin. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Britain Loses 276,000 Jobs Since Reeves’ Tax-Raising Budget
item.description: UK employment plunged by the most in five years and wage growth slowed more than forecast, in the clearest sign yet that Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ budget was fueling a deterioration in the British jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Commuters climb the stairs to exit Liverpool Street railway station in London, UK.

item.title: South Korea Appoints Yeo as Trade Minister to Lead Talks With US
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung appointed Yeo Han-koo, a seasoned trade negotiator, as the new trade minister to guide the country through ongoing tariff talks with the US.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Namibia to Raise $122 Million to Refinance Eurobond Due October
item.description: Namibia plans to raise $122 million in the domestic market to refinance a portion of its $750 million eurobond due October and will use a sinking fund to retire the balance, its Finance Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Kaula Nhongo

media:content.media:description: A road leading to the port in Walvis Bay, Namibia.

item.title: From Visas to Jets, US and China Are Finding New Trade Leverage
item.description: Donald Trump brought many of the same grievances to his second trade war against China, but the economic battleground that’s emerged since then is making it harder to avoid a rupture this time around.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: ECB Can Still Move Quickly to Adjust Rates, Villeroy Says
item.description: The European Central Bank could still move quickly to adjust interest rates even after an eighth successive cut “normalized” monetary policy, according to Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sends Two Aircraft Carriers Into Pacific Ocean in a First
item.description: Japan said it observed two Chinese aircraft carriers and supporting warships operating simultaneously near remote Japanese islands in the Pacific Ocean for the first time, a new demonstration of Beijing’s advancing naval capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: The Shandong aircraft carrier at a naval port in Sanya in 2019. Photographer: Li Gang/Xinhua/Getty Images

item.title: Norway’s Core Inflation Slows More Than Forecast to 2025 Low
item.description: Norway’s underlying inflation rate declined slightly more than expected in May, cementing the case for Norges Bank to begin interest-rate cuts in coming months.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Says Inflation Is Still Below Target, Weakening Yen
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank is still some distance from its inflation goal in comments that helped accelerate a weakening of the yen.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg
